intro: Phaeopappus gabrieliae, commonly known as the Gabriel's pappus, is a rare flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive leaf structures. The plant has dark green, lance-shaped leaves with hairy surfaces, and its flowers are typically yellow to orange in color. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is often found in mountainous regions. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
